title: 道德經
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.en: (The empty heart, or the Dao in its operation) The grandest forms of active force from Dao come, their only source.
Who can of Dao the nature tell? Our sight it flies, our touch as well.
Eluding sight, eluding touch, the forms of things all in it crouch;
Eluding touch, eluding sight, there are their semblances, all right.
Profound it is, dark and obscure; things' essences all there endure.
Those essences the truth enfold of what, when seen, shall then be told.

passages.zh: 自古及今，其名不去，以閱衆甫。
passages.en: Now it is so; 'twas so of old. Its name - what passes not away; so, in their beautiful array, things form and never know decay.

passages.zh: 吾何以知衆甫之狀哉？以此。
passages.en: How know I that it is so with all the beauties of existing things? By this (nature of the Dao).
